section.name: PATHOGENESIS OF MENTAL DISORDERS ACROSS THE LIFESPAN

comments:
The conceptual and practice application of brain-behavior relationships for
individuals with mental health and psychiatric conditions is developed in this course.
Students learn interview and differential diagnostic skills to screen for
neuropsychological etiologies of mental disorders such as schizophrenia, bipolar
disorders, mood disorders and anxiety disorders. The course reviews specific theories of
etiology and diagnostic classifications found in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of
Mental Disorders-Fourth Edition- Text Revision (DSM IV- TR). Students develop the
ability to make critical decisions as they learn finer points of differential diagnosing of
mental disorders using a case based method of learning, allowing students to focus on
specific populations such as aged, adults, adolescents, and children.
While students enjoyed the class and found the lectures interesting, they believed
the course was not as focused as it might have been. Many student felt they learned a lot,
but not quite as much as they expected regarding the pathology of disease itself. The
lectures were described as interesting and provided numerous case studies to enhance the
material. Students were impressed by the course design.
Across the board, students appreciate Dr. Tckas as a professor for this material.
They commented that he was a skilled lecturer and would have preferred if there were
fewer guest lecturers and Dr. Tckas had covered all the material instead.
Students did not seem overwhelmed by the coursework. Some did feel, though,
that the course was challenging because the material assumed that students already had a
rather advanced understanding of topics, such as neuroanatomy.
